I followed her eyes, and saw the white dot far below in the valley of the blue river. It was the first glimpse of the Borgo Pass which I had yet had, and I was struck by the utter desolation of the scene. The road winds and doubles so that the effect is that of a serpent among the rocks. The pass is a sort of tunnel through the great mountain, and the river runs under the road through a cutting, so that the sound of its rushing is always in the ears. The mountains are so steep and rocky that there is no possibility of climbing them, and the road, always dangerous, is here more than usually so. I was looking at it with an experienced eye, and I could see the difficulties which might be made by the least mischance. The mere thought of it made me shiver, and I turned to Mina to ask her to get in, for the air was cold and the wind was beginning to blow. But she did not hear me, or, rather, she did not seem to hear me. She was still looking fixedly towards the pass, and her eyes had an intent, far-away look which I had never seen in them before. I was about to speak to her again, when I noticed that the men had all got down from the box, and were standing looking towards the pass in the same fixed way. I felt a shiver run down my spine as our eyes met, and I knew that I was face to face with the enemy. I tried to speak, but my voice caught in my throat, and I could only point towards the carriage.
